misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array index boundary misconception (off-by-one / last index confusion)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array of length n has a valid element at index n (i.e., the “nth element” is stored at arr[n]) and that shifting can safely write to arr[n] when moving elements right.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed: valid indices are 0 to n-1. The last element is arr[n-1], not arr[n]. Accessing or assigning arr[n] always causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. A right-shift must save arr[n-1], then move elements into indices 1..n-1, then place the saved value at arr[0].
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) for any n > 0 during the shift step.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when accessing array elements during a right shift operation, they should use loop bounds from 1 to n (inclusive) rather than 0 to n-1. They think this will correctly access all elements of an array of size n.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has a flawed understanding of array indexing in Java. Arrays are zero-indexed, meaning valid indices range from 0 to n-1 for an array of size n. When the student uses loop bounds `i = 1` to `i <= n`, they attempt to access arr[n], which is out of bounds and causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The correct loop should use `i = 0` to `i < n` or `i = 1` to `i < n` with adjusted index calculations.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when attempting to execute the right shift logic at line 18 where `arr[n]` is accessed.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for an array of size n, the valid indices range from 1 to n, and specifically that the last element is stored at index n.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays use zero-based indexing. For an array of size n, the indices range from 0 to n-1. Attempting to access or assign to index n results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException because it is outside the bounds of the allocated memory.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array length vs last valid index (0-based indexing boundary confusion)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for an array of size n, the last element is at index n (and that it is safe to read/write arr[n]).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed, so valid indices are 0 through n-1. Accessing arr[n] is always out of bounds and causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when n > 0; program does not produce the shifted output.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Inclusive loop bounds when shifting array elements
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the shifting loop should start at i = n and go down to 1, assigning arr[i] from arr[i-1].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: When shifting right by one, you must copy from the last valid index (n-1) down to 1, i.e., for (i = n-1; i >= 1; i--). Starting at i = n attempts to write arr[n], which is outside the array.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception during the first iteration of the shift loop for n > 0.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that in an array of size n, valid indices range from 0 to n (inclusive), and that arr[n] is a valid position. They also believe that to shift all elements, they should loop from i=n down to i=1, assigning arr[i] = arr[i-1] to shift each element.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has a fundamental misunderstanding of array bounds in Java. Arrays of size n have valid indices from 0 to n-1, not 0 to n. The last element is at index n-1, not n. When the code attempts to access arr[n], it exceeds the array bounds and causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime. The student correctly applied index conversion (arr[i-1]) in the input loop but failed to apply the same logic in the shift logic, indicating inconsistent understanding of 0-based indexing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when attempting to read arr[n]

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for an array of size 'n', the valid range of indices includes 'n'. They assume the last element is stored at index 'n' and that they can assign a value to index 'n' during the shifting process.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed, meaning an array defined with size 'n' has valid indices from 0 to n-1. Attempting to access 'arr[n]' triggers an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException because 'n' is beyond the upper bound of the array.
